author: mklement0
body:
For a real-life case of the behavior described being problematic, see [this StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/57734162/45375), where a user puzzles over ashorcut-file-launched PowerShell window instantly closing, despite use of `-NoExit`.

Note: The correct behavior is debatable, but to me it makes more sense to give more weight to `-NoExit` -  i.e. to the request to open _an interactive shell_ - over erroring out due to not being able to find the script file targeted (as long as the command line is otherwise _syntactically_ correct).

Note that passing a broken _command_ with `-Command` already behaves that way; e.g.:

```
pwsh -nop -noexit -c '1 / '  # new session is still entered, despite broken command.
```

# Steps to reproduce

Enter interactively, one line after the other:

```powershell
$PID
pwsh -noprofile -noexit -file ./nosuchscript.ps1
$PID
```

# Expected behavior

```none
<PID of calling shell>
<error message about not finding the script>
<PID of *new* shell>
```

That is, a new shell should _always_ be entered, since the command line was _syntactically_ correct and `-NoExit` was specified.

# Actual behavior

```none
<PID of calling shell>
<error message about not finding the script>
<PID of calling shell>
```

**That is, despite `-NoExit`, the new process _exited unconditionally_**, due to not finding the script specified as the `-File` argument.

Note that, by contrast, if the script _can_ be found and throws a terminating error, the shell is (rightfully) _not_ exited.

# Environment data

```none
PowerShell Core 7.0.0-preview.3
Windows PowerShell v5.1.18362.145 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; Version 1903, OS Build: 18362.295)
```
title: CLI: -NoExit doesn't keep the shell open if the -File argument (script file path) cannot be found
